conclusion: To solve for the temperature at state C, analyze the given information and use the ideal gas law.
Understanding the ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
At state A: Volume VA = V0, Temperature TA = T0, Pressure PA = P0.
Using the ideal gas law at state A: P0 V0 = n R T0.
At state B: Volume VB = 2V0, Temperature TB unknown, Pressure PB unknown.
Since AB is parallel to the V-axis, pressure remains constant: PB = P0.
Using the ideal gas law at state B: P0 * 2V0 = n R TB.
Relating states A and B: 2 = TB/T0, so TB = 2T0.
At state C: Volume VC unknown, Temperature TC unknown, Pressure PC unknown.
The extension line of BC is over the origin, implying a linear relationship: P = kV.
From state B: P0 * 2V0 = k, so k = 2P0 V0.
For state C: PC VC = 2P0 V0.
Relating states B and C: VC/VB = TC/TB, so VC = (TC/T0) * V0.
Solving for TC: VC = (TC/T0) V0, so TC = T0.
The temperature at state C is T0.
